Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The Developmental Origins of Human Cooperation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Humans share valuable resources, assist others who need help, and work together in teams to produce outcomes that lie beyond the capabilities of any one individual. Yet the origins of these cooperative abilities are a puzzle. Other species do not seem to engage in similar behaviors--indeed, humans have been characterized as a hyper-cooperative primate. One way to address why humans show these cooperative patterns is to examine how young children acquire these skills. Are young children initially selfish, and must be taught to become altruistic? Or do humans have a biological predisposition for altruism that even children exhibit? How do children learn to share a common resource and acquire ideas about fairness? With support of a NSF CAREER award, Dr. Felix Warneken (Harvard University) will conduct a comprehensive developmental study of children's cooperative behaviors.

This research aims to investigate the fundamental psychological processes that enable young children to cooperate with others. How do children detect that another person is in need? Under what circumstances are they motivated to help? By using experimental studies of young children, this research can address important questions about the interplay of biological predispositions found early in development and the socialization practices that influence the further development of these behaviors. In particular, the research will investigate when social expectations and norms that characterize cooperative behaviors in adults begin to play a role in child development. For example, adults often expect others to reciprocate favors and have norms about what constitutes a fair share of a valuable resource. Therefore, this research is to determine when during development children begin to attend to these norms when they cooperate with others. By integrating insights from evolutionary theory, social psychology, and child development, this project provides a comprehensive study of the skill-set for cooperation that children acquire across development. In addition, this research program will provide a wide range of training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students in developmental psychology, including active participation of students in research, and a summer internship program with stipends for undergraduate students from underrepresented groups. It will also educate the broader public about psychological research through freely available educational material about the research projects for classroom instructors and the greater public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual goal of this project was to investigate the fundamental psychological processes that enable young children to cooperate with others. How do children detect that another person is in need? What motivates children to cooperate with others? What is the interplay of biological predispositions found early in development and the socialization practices that influence the further development of cooperative behaviors? The project yielded both advances in theory and novel empirical research findings. Specifically, the project tested a new theoretical framework integrating concepts from biology, social psychology, and developmental psychology to explain when and how different aspects of children’s cooperative abilities emerge over development, including capacities for helping others, sharing resources, and reciprocating such acts of cooperation.

First, this new theoretical framework motivated a series of empirical studies investigating critical cooperative skills in children. This included studies of helping behaviors in young children, revealing what cues children need to know when others need help, and the circumstances under which they offer help spontaneously. Several studies investigated children’s earliest sharing behaviors, showing how children over development become able to share with others in a reciprocal fashion by sharing more valuable resources when individuals are sharing back with them in the future. These studies highlighted important cognitive and social-cognitive skills that scaffold mature social skills, such as being able to think about the future and differentiating between trustworthy and untrustworthy social partners. Finally, our work showed the increasingly important role of fairness norms over development in guiding children’s cooperative decision-making. In particular, we showed that young children share resources based upon merit by sharing more with collaborators than non-collaborators, and are increasingly more likely to apply equality norms during the school-age years when deciding how resources should be distributed. Finally, we took the paradigms developed in the course of this project and adapted them for larger-scale cross-cultural comparisons across multiple societies. This line of work revealed both important similarities and differences in fairness-based sharing across children from diverse populations across the world, highlighting which aspects of sharing are more common and which aspects rely more strongly on local fairness norms and thus are more socially malleable. These empirical studies were published in peer-reviewed journals and the novel framework proposed and tested in the project resulted in a series of theoretical papers and reviews published in journals such as Annual Review of Psychology and Nature Human Behaviour.

         A second major aspect of this project was to provide a wide range of training opportunities for students. For the duration of the project, over 150 undergraduate students were able to actively participate in research during the school year and a newly established 10-week summer internship program offered each year. As part of the summer internship program, stipends for students from underrepresented minorities allowed for novel educational experiences in research and professional development to prepare for graduate school. A second goal for the educational component of the project was the design of a novel course that teaches undergraduate students about the most recent developments in the study of cooperation, integrating findings from developmental as well as social psychology, as well as from biology. This course is now offered annually at the University of Michigan and highly popular among students in psychology and related disciplines. A third educational goal was to educate the broader public about psychological research through freely available educational material and active participation. The project joined a collaboration with two local museums where children and their families participate in research and learn about psychology. Additionally, students working at the museums receive training in public science communication. Lastly, findings from the project are accessible through an educational website maintained by the PI where video examples from psychological studies as well as public talks by the PI to be used by course instructors and the greater public.
